channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Candidate Rises on Vows to Control Islam and Immigration. This Time in France.
item.media:description: Supporters of Mr. Fillon during a campaign event in Chassieu, France, on Tuesday. “He really respects French values, and that is very, very important to us,” one supporter said.
item.description: François Fillon’s promises to limit immigration and protect conservative values in France have helped propel him to the front of the presidential field.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Inside a Fake News Sausage Factory: ‘This Is All About Income’
item.media:description: A fake news article posted by Beqa Latsabidze, a Georgian. “My audience likes Trump,” he said. “I don’t want to write bad things about Trump. If I write fake stories about Trump, I lose my audience.”
item.description: A computer science student in a former Soviet republic found there was money to be made in mixing real and made-up stories, as long as they were pro-Trump.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS, MIKE McINTIRE and GABRIEL J.X. DANCE

item.title: In Scotland, Trump Built a Wall. Then He Sent Residents the Bill.
item.media:description: From their kitchen window, John and Susan Munro used to have a view of the Scottish coastline, until it was blocked by an earthen berm built by Mr. Trump’s people.
item.media:credit: Jeremy Sutton-Hibbert for The New York Times
item.description: The president-elect left a trail of unmet promises on one of his golf courses, and lashed out at homeowners who stood in his way.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Ukraine’s Ex-Leader Regrets Not Breaking Up Protests That Led to His Fall
item.media:description: Viktor F. Yanukovych, the former president of Ukraine.
item.description: Viktor F. Yanukovych, the former president of Ukraine, said that his “main mistake” was not declaring martial law, but that he did not want to cause a civil war.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Erdogan Threatens to Let Migrant Flood Into Europe Resume
item.description: Turkey’s president accused the European Union of not keeping its commitments, and he suggested he might allow migrants to cross Turkish borders again.
item.dc:creator: SAFAK TIMUR and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Hungry Venezuelans Flee in Boats to Escape Economic Collapse
item.media:description: Migrants preparing to board the smugglers’ boats that will take them from Venezuela to Curaçao.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Well over 150,000 people have fled Venezuela in the last year alone, the most in more than a decade, scholars say, with the sea route posing special dangers.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Opera Maestro Ensnared in Brazilian Graft Scandal Lashes Out at Accusers
item.media:description: The Brazilian conductor and artistic director John Neschling, left, with two of his advisers in São Paulo. He says lawbreakers are smearing him to get leniency through plea deals.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Using the court of public opinion, John Neschling, who has not been charged with a crime, questions whether Brazil’s graft fight also entangles the innocent.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Brazil’s President, Michel Temer, Embroiled in New Corruption Scandal
item.media:description: President Michel Temer in Brasília in October. He rose to power six months ago after the impeachment of his predecessor, Dilma Rousseff.
item.description: Marcelo Calero, a former culture minister, said Mr. Temer had pressured him on behalf of a top ally. Critics are demanding the president’s impeachment.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Scott Dayton Identified as First American to Die in Syria Combat
item.media:description: Senior Chief Petty Officer Scott C. Dayton, who lived in Woodbridge, Va., was killed by an improvised bomb on Thursday in northern Syria.
item.description: Chief Dayton, who lived in Virginia and was assigned to a bomb-disposal unit, was killed in northern Syria on Thursday by an improvised bomb.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Israel Arrests 22 Over Wildfires, as Arson Is Suspected
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that the blazes, which have burned many homes and forced residents to flee, were acts of “terror.”
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Indian Vendors See Empty Stores and Blame a Rupee Ban
item.media:description: A flower market in Bangalore, India, on Thursday. Indian businesses tied to the vast informal economy have been virtually paralyzed since a surprise ban on some currency notes.
item.description: When Prime Minister Narendra Modi banned the 500- and 1,000-rupee bills, his goal was to spur the economy. But the move seems to be having the opposite effect.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Memo From Beijing: With North Korea Looming, Trump May Be Rethinking China Showdown
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump campaigning in Council Bluffs, Iowa, in September. As president-elect, he has shown signs of shifting his focus in Asia toward North Korea and its nuclear arsenal.
item.description: Starting a trade war would jeopardize Beijing’s cooperation on containing the North, whose nuclear capabilities have been increasing sharply.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: What in the World: Which Language Uses the Most Sounds? Click 5 Times for the Answer
item.media:description: Speakers of Khoisan languages, like the San people in Namibia, use click consonants, packing a lot of information into brief words.
item.description: Taa, spoken by a few thousand people in Botswana and Namibia, is believed to have the largest sound inventory of any language in the world.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Bernardo Álvarez, Hugo Chávez’s Envoy in Washington, Dies at 60
item.media:description: Bernardo Álvarez Herrera, who was seen as a pragmatist, served as ambassador to the United States from 2003 to 2010.
item.media:credit: Carol T. Powers for The New York Times
item.description: American officials saw Mr. Álvarez, Venezuela’s ambassador from 2003 to 2010, as a pragmatist who prevented ties between the countries from fraying further.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: From Putin’s Hands: A Russian Passport for Steven Seagal
item.media:description: The French actor Gerard Depardieu, left, with President Vladimir V. Putin in Sochi, Russia, in 2013. Mr. Depardieu sought Russian citizenship as part of his battle against higher taxes.
item.media:credit: Mikhail Klimentyev/RIA Novosti Kremlin, via Associated Press
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin personally handed the document on Friday to the action film star, who received Russian citizenship earlier this month.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Canada Today: Algae Blooms, Fighter Jets and Fund-Raising Trouble
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada held a press conference at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit in Lima, Peru, last week.
item.description: He toughened guidelines on donations, but Justin Trudeau still finds himself drawn into a debate about Liberal Party gatherings with donors.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Prosecutor Says Arrests Disrupted ‘Imminent’ ISIS Attack in France
item.media:description: The Paris prosecutor, François Molins, after delivering a statement on Friday about the investigation into what he said was a thwarted terrorist plot.
item.description: Five men who were arrested in Strasbourg and Marseille were directed by a commander in Iraq or Syria, the French authorities said Friday.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Life Term in Killings of 4 Gay Men; Police Face Scrutiny Over Efforts
item.media:description: Stephen Port, 41, was given a life sentence on Friday.
item.description: The Independent Police Complaints Commission has begun a formal investigation into the actions of 17 officers, including whether “discrimination played any part in actions and decisions.”
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: U.N. Offers ‘One-Off’ Help to Australia in Resettling Refugees in U.S.
item.media:description: Protesters in Sydney, Australia, this month demanding humane treatment for asylum seekers.
item.description: The agreement, which officials say is not to be replicated, would send some of the asylum seekers now detained on remote islands to the United States.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees

item.title: Indian Court Bans Fireworks Sales in Delhi to Fight Smog
item.media:description: Smog enveloping New Delhi on Oct. 31.
item.description: Though a longstanding custom at Hindu festivals, the displays were seen as contributing to dangerous levels of air pollution.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Sinosphere: Calls for Hong Kong Independence Hurt Push for Democracy, Ex-Governor Says
item.media:description: Christopher F. Patten, the former British colonial governor of Hong Kong, speaking at the Foreign Correspondents’ Club in Hong Kong on Friday.
item.description: The comments, by Christopher F. Patten, offered a prominent rebuke to a separatist movement struggling for representation in the local legislature.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Opinion: The Two Putin Problem
item.media:description: A journalist taking notes during a telecast of the presidential election results in front of portraits of Donald J. Trump and Vladimir V. Putin in a Moscow pub.
item.description: One is confident, the other defensive. Trump will have to deal with both.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN SESTANOVICH
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Editorial: Taiwan as a Same-Sex Marriage Pioneer
item.description: The Taiwanese government could send a powerful message as the first in Asia to legalized same sex unions.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Editorial: Warning Russia on Hacking Isn’t Enough
item.description: Because Mr. Trump, an outspoken admirer of Mr. Putin, is unlikely to act, it is up to Mr. Obama to hold the Russian president to account.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
